title: Friday, 1st February 2019
bodyHTML:

11:12 am

Off we go then. February 1st. Hope you had a good transfer deadline day.

Catgotmytongue Morning
Manxish Happy Friday, everyone

Seems my move to Unilad fell through at the last minute. So we're still doing this. Where to begin?

The numbers were in line to slightly better. The 2019 guidance plays into the thesis that you own Amazon for what it'll become .....

red basically powell admitted he is the mkts b***h. it would be unheard of 25 years ago. u can mitigate by says we are in unconventional times with unconventional policies in play, but still...

.... ie, a listed empirical nation-state ....

11:21 am

BE11:22am

Here's Barclays.

BE11:22am

The Key Take-Away: AMZN reported rev& OI largely in-line with consensus, and guided in-line at the high-end of the range. The biggest question we are pondering coming off the print is whether AMZN leaning into heavier investmentsin 2019 will lead to accelerating growth rates (as was the case in 16/17) or suboptimal teens growth with contracting margin. AWS continues to be the stand-out performer with revenue exceeding our expectations at +46% Y/Y. Stepping back, the 20% pullback in AMZN since September2018 (vs. -7% S&P), in our view,prices in much of the concerns around growth & pace of margin expansion in retail, and we would let the dust settle & add on weakness.

11:22 am
BE11:22am

Positives In 4Q:AWSgrowth held 46% ex-fx, accelerating on a 2-yr stack, & continues to lead the industry in dollar-growth meaningfully. AWS operating margin expanded 280bps Y/Y which drove AWS OI up 61%. Given the strong cadence AWS is worth nearly 2/3rds of AMZN’s aggregate market cap in our view (at 8x revenue). In retail, 1-P growth accelerated to 14% Y/Y (from 11%), which combined with solid 3-P growth of 28%, helped propel international acceleration in 4Q. Retail operating margin expanded 110bps Y/Y, a slight downtick from the prior cadence but strong nonetheless

BE11:22am

Negatives To Monitor:The very high margin advertising revenue within retail decelerated sharply in 4Q, as Other revenue growth was 39% (organic ex-606) vs.56%in 3Q. The key line that cuts through a lot of noise is retail GP growth ex-WFM, which decelerated from 38% to 23% Y/Y ex-fx. A combination of 1) modest shipping cost de-leverage, 2) slower ads & subscription revgrowth, and 3) lower 3-P mix, were likely the factors that drove the deceleration. Amazon plans on investing more heavily in 2019 after a 14%-15% fulfilment sq ft and headcount growthyear in 2018, which will slow the pace of retail OI expansion to some degree but may lead to higher revenue growth.

DJ @red everyone just knows that stocks are overvalued and nobody's ready for a huge crash and its knock-on effects so we continue the dance for a little longer
BE11:24am

Amazon Frankfurt quote looks to be down 4.7%.

wayneJ @red - I think it was more significant than that. He specifically mentioned overseas economy. I have long argued that the Fed sets policy for the US but actually influences the entire dollar zone. And the dollar zone includes countries with pegs (hard or soft) to the USD (or that are dependent on USD priced commodities)
11:24 am
BE11:24am

Which feels aggressive.

BE11:24am

Morgan Stanley:

BE11:25am

Looking to 1Q, the top end of 1Q rev guide was 2% below us and the top
end of EBIT guide was 7% ($250mn) below us. While 1Q revenue was light and 4Q deals/discounting speak to a competitive holiday space, the other sources of downside are essentially investment. Investment isn’t going to let up (it’s a way of life at AMZN) as AMZN intends to invest in headcount, fulfillment capacity, and data centers in 2019. But a slower growing top-line combined with this investment is going to pressure near-term profitability as we lower our ‘19/’20 GAAP EBIT by 5%/12%.

wayneJ But the China effect is also important for a secondary impact - rising rates in the US suck liquidity from other parts of the dollar zone ie China hence falling money supply in China hence dropping the RRR and PBOC pumping liquidity.
11:25 am
BE11:25am

Why is Amazon Growth Slowing? In our view, these results and continued
investment speak to how incremental e-commerce growth is becoming
somewhat more difficult and expensive. The 2017/2018 tailwinds have lost some luster as we believe US Prime sub growth is slowing (now at 50%+ penetration), AMZN is already driving ~70% of every incremental dollar of growth within its core addressable US PCE, and AMZN’s international business hasn’t been able to grow as quickly as hoped – in particular beyond UK/Germany/Japan. But this doesn’t change our view of AMZN’s ability to drive higher long-term gross profit and EPS growth…with the key being AMZN’s ability to scale/gain traction in new US categories (like the ~$840bn US grocery industry), countries (Western Europe, India, ASEAN) and business lines (more advertising, logistics, and healthcare).

BE11:26am

They're bulls.

BornCynic For the stuff that I buy eBay is regularly cheaper than Amazon now.
BE11:26am

The good news is 1) Amazon still has a scaling bucket of high margin AWS,
advertising and subscription revenue streams that we see enabling the company to re-invest and drive faster growth. Consider that we now have $14bn in net retail losses (from investment) in 2019 vs $12bn in 2018. 2) They have done this before across multiple categories and industries (retail – category by category, AWS, logistics, etc) and 3) AMZN has been planting investment seeds in multiple areas over the past few years that are likely to be the key to driving reacceleration. We fully acknowledge building/scaling these business could take time…but valuation isn’t stretched compared to growth (15X 2020 adj. EBITDA for a 23% '18-21 growth CAGR, roughly in par with consumer staples despite growing EBITDA ~5x faster). Looking ahead, upward revisions (and executing within these sectors) will be important to driving outperformance.

wayneJ (Semi-)fixed RMB / USD rate means that as money flows out of China and is converted from RMB to USD the PBOC has to sell USD ie US treasuries at the same time as QT and US corporates liquidating overseas 'cash' holdings which are often in US Ts

BE11:26am

Reducing '19/'20 EBIT by 5/11%, PT to $2,200 but Remain Overweight

In addition, TALK is citing FibreNation costs of £5-10m, guiding its reported EBITDA will be £235-245m, implying c8% downgrades to cons EBITDA.

Subscriber growth but ARPU growth still negative - TALK has reported 3Q results with on-net revenue growth of 2.9% (vs 3.2% 2Q19, 4.1% 1Q19), driving total headline revenue growth of 2.9% (vs +3.7% 2Q19,-1.8% 1Q19).
KPI’s – We note TALK added 44k broadband customers (vs 24k 2Q19, 80k 1Q19). We note overall the market (BT Openreach) added 95k and Vodafone within this added 46k with VMED yet to report. On-net ARPU growth came in at -2% (vs 1.7% at 2Q) driven by weaker mix and tough competition and churn was 1.2% (vs 1.2% at 2Q). FIbre net adds were strong in the quarter with 146k net adds (vs. 125k 2Q19, 1Q19)

11:37 am
BE11:37am

Overall another quarter of strong customer growth for TalkTalk with TalkTalk having added 146,000 broadband customers in the financial year to date compared to its FY19 target of more than 150,000. However, TalkTalk has missed our Q3FY19 revenue (ex-MVNO) by 2.6% and it has cut its FY19 EBITDA guidance to £245-250m from an implied £261m previously.
While we believe TalkTalk has executed very well on subscriber growth over the past few quarters, we have seen the company miss our revenue forecasts for the past 3 quarters and its EBITDA guidance for FY19 has been cut again.
The key question for us remains how much TalkTalk is discounting price and spending in acquisition costs to achieve this strong subscriber growth.
We look to the Q3 call at 8.30am today to get more detail on the level of
discounting and acquisition costs.
Credit Suisse TalkTalk stock view
We still view TalkTalk as structurally challenged as (1) UK FTTH build
continues to slowly ramp (e.g. CityFibre/Vodafone & Openreach); and (2) the risk to DSL from mobile substitution rises. TalkTalk's own fibre ambitions remain modest near-term and, in our view, it would need a well-funded partner to successfully build a material fibre footprint in the UK.
We rate TalkTalk Underperform.

Pharma @wayneJ AMZ benefited early on from the "no sales tax on internet purchases", but that depended on not having a base in a particular state. They are now too big, and presumably have warehouses etc. in most states.

Management were keen to highlight the positives around customer momentum, but questions were more skeptical around:

Higher leverage with net debt to EBITDA expected to continue to trend at
over 3x. Management say they have more than enough dividend capacity
(eg, from previous equity raise/ other sources), but this is topical because
the dividend was only recently cut in Feb 2018.
Higher capex of £13-14mn (together with the earlier announced higher
opex) relating to investments in FibreNation.
Higher restructuring costs of £25-30mn to execute the simplification plan.

BE11:39am

Management say they are comfortable with FY20 EBITDA consensus estimates, but the market is understandably concerned given numerous downgrades in recent years (with the latest downgrade only this morning).

11:40 am
BE11:40am

First, TALK has cut guidance for FY19 EBITDA by 4-6%, before another 2-4% hit due to its FTTP venture, FibreNation. Second, subscriber growth in the last few quarters has exceeded consensus expectations but revenue growth continues to decelerate. Third, we understand net debt/EBITDA at the end of FY19 will be approximately 3.5x rather than in the region of 2.7x TALK expected c.6 months ago. Fourth, we remain worried that TALK will waste significant capital on FibreNation. Lastly, TALK is confident of earning FY20 EBITDA in line with consensus estimates (£271m) but, for one, TALK has been confident of several things in the past but not delivered. We will adjust our forecasts (and therefore also our Target Price) as soon as we process all the detail of today. We retain our bearish stance on ths stock.

Deutsche has reported 4Q18 statutory pre-tax loss of -€0.3bn, similar
to consensus, but the underlying pre-tax loss (ex. restructuring, litigation, disposals, DVA, etc), of -€0.3m is notably worse than consensus, which assumed a +€0.1bn profit. By division the underlying miss is across all three core divisions, with a sizeable loss from CIB during the quarter. Reiterate Sell/H rating.

11:47 am
BE11:47am

Deutsche Bank has reiterated the target greater than 4% RoTE for 2019 (excl. AT1 coupon cost) vs 0.5% in 2018. The new disclosure is that c2.5% of the improvement is driven by existing identified measures (balance sheet optimization, cost reduction, etc) vs greater than 1% on a more constructive market environment and market share gains. Consensus (and Citi) is for c3%, so appears sceptical on the latter. The new cost target of c€21.8bn for 2019 compares favourably to the old target and consensus of c€22bn. This is driven by FTE reduction & synergies with Postbank.

And on overview.

BE11:48am

Underlying PBT is below consensus, mainly driven by weaker CIB
revenues, largely relating to FICC. Although management has delivered on costs and balance sheet reduction, this seems to have come at the expense of revenues. The bank still appears to be losing CIB market share, which we fear will continue. Consequently we expect to see low-single digit consensus EPS downgrades.

Pharma i.e. the border will be leaky, and people will try to smuggle goods with high *excise* duties, just as they do now.
11:48 am
BE11:48am

Kepler too.

BE11:48am

Deutsche Bank (Sell): Weak results in Q4 2018 In Q4, revenues were down by 2% YOY due mainly to lower fixed income
sales. Costs were reduced by 19% but the cost/income ratio remained
above 100%. The bank posted a net loss and the FL CET1 dropped by
0.4pp to 13.6%. On the positive side, DB reaffirmed its targets for 2019
and provided reassurance that it would be able to pay a coupon. DB also
succeeded in achieving its 2018 targets turning a profit for full year 2018
(for the first time in four years). Speculation about a potential merger by
mid-year emerged again. We maintain our Sell recommendation.

BE11:49am

wayneJ @Pharma - the WTO rules require us to have the same tariffs on all countries that we do not have a FTA with. As we are not set up to process and do customs checks my thought is that we ought to impose WTO recommended tariffs and so will do so but in practise we will wave trucks from Europe through.Hence legit co.s eg supermarkets and reputable pub operators will register and ensure compliance. But in the desperation to avoid queues smaller 'entrepreneurs' will escape. So there will be an 'arb'' between European produce that has had tariffs and that which has not. But as we will have to impose WTO tariffs on European goods the arb will be bigger than now
BE11:51am

The plan currently seems to be cutting costs faster than revenue deteriorates, which is a risky game when your entire business is some people in suits sitting at computers.

BE11:51am

Here's Morgan Stanley off the conference call.

FATDAZ @Pharma judging by a report on the BBC about circulation of ' Fake ' cigarettes in the UK the smuggler have very efficient logistics and supply chain
11:51 am
BE11:52am

Quarterly call focused on three key things:
1. Capital: still no guidance provided on regulatory RWA inflation of Basel
4/FRTB impact. T1 Leverage target of 4.5% remains a medium-term target;
trajectory unclear given current starting point at 4.1% and intent to grow
leverage, particularly via lending.
2. Revenue trajectory: remains dependent on market conditions. One area called out again was optimization of liquidity buffers, potentially adding E300mn of revenues in 2019 (MSe incorporates this uplift in 2020e). Unclear trajectory on CIB top line. No commentary on Ytd trends.
3. Costs. Management had high conviction in 2019e target delivery – €21.8bn new target announced – further ~3k personnel reduction in PCB + support functions, Continued optimization of real estate portfolio/external services + vendors helps non-personnel cost savings.
4. Target ROTE of greater than 4% in 2019 – post AT1 coupons implied at 3.4% – of which 1% improvement dependent on conducive market conditions in CIB.
We remain Underweight, with a PT of €8. The stock trades on 0.3x P/TBV 2019e and 13x EPS, against European banks at 9x.

undefined

wayneJ I think the key thing that is being missed is that WTO rules do not mean an open market - unless it is open to everyone - and in that case the UK economy implodes as local produces get hit.

Smuggling is duty arbitrage, and when we leave we would have the opportunity to reduce tariffs to the point where it was not worthwhile. Save everyone a great deal of time and trouble.

wayneJ 'The long list of earlier accusations was never proven' - I seem to recall that the proof was in the earlier documents. The issue was really that the co. did not provide an alternative explanation and there was no visibility on its 'independent' investigation?
